title: About
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Murat Seyhan, a data scientist with a passion for the sea. I‚Äôve always believed that life is a blend of structure and flow, much like the balance between my gusto for data and the open sea. Let me introduce myself in a few words.

DATA SCIENCE
Professionally, I‚Äôm a Data Scientist, where I‚Äôve specialized in discovering patterns in chaos. Essentially it‚Äôs really just a fancy way of saying I help make sense of things that seem too big or complicated for our intuition. From predictive analytics to crafting intuitive dashboards, I‚Äôve always sought to make complex data tell a clear story. Along the way, I‚Äôve had the chance to work on projects that transformed raw numbers into actionable insights, gaining valuable experience at organizations like Garanti BBVA and KPMG.


FOOTBALL ANALYTICS
One of my recent passions is football analytics. Using Python, I dive into match data to uncover insights and create visualizations. I‚Äôm working on ways to bring these analyses to a wider audience, bringing together my interest in sports and data.


SAILING ADVENTURES
During my university years, I found myself not just studying Economics but working as a sailing instructor, teaching students of all levels‚Äîfrom beginners to competitive racers‚Äîhow to handle boats and embrace the wind. This role was deeply fulfilling, combining my love for the sport with the joy of teaching. At the same time, I founded a Sailing Club in Marmara University, creating a vibrant community of students who bonded over the wind and waves. Leading such a community of students was a defining experience‚Äîteaching and learning from others, both on the water and off.


MUSIC & CREATIVITY
When I‚Äôm not immersed in data or the sea, I turn to music for a creative outlet. Playing the guitar, performing live, or producing melodies has been a part of my life since 2014. It‚Äôs my way of expressing creativity and connecting with others.
This is me in a snapshot‚Äîsomeone who finds joy in analyzing data, navigating the seas, creating music, and exploring football through numbers. If any of this resonates, I‚Äôd love to connect and share more!

title: The Illusion of Form: Regression to the Mean in Football
text:
There is an evident statistical regularity hidden in plain sight ‚Äî one that, when ignored, quietly shapes football narratives, fuels misjudgments, and silently distorts careers: regression to the mean.
If you‚Äôre a football fan, like me ‚Äî since the beginning of my childhood ‚Äî big effect of my grandfather being a fan and serving on the council committee of Be≈üikta≈ü JK. And if you‚Äôre a football fan, with the pull of confirmation bias, you‚Äôre often inclined to validate your team‚Äôs decisions, even when they‚Äôre performing bad. You see what you hope to see. Or sometimes you‚Äôre affected by the crowd‚Äôs opinion, and make up stories about the bad performance, usually ends up finding a scapegoat, perfect fit for the situation. And boo him/her, maybe?
And in most football clubs ‚Äî especially the ones that are not data-driven or digital-native (which is most of them, outside the privileged few) ‚Äî the decision-making at the management level is often no different from that of the fans. In some contexts, it may even be worse.
They, too, seek causality. They crave a clean narrative, and illuminate the ambiguity. But football doesn‚Äôt always offer causal clarity. And in that search for meaning, we often miss what‚Äôs actually going on: plain old randomness. It shows up looking like form, momentum, or a player in decline ‚Äî but it‚Äôs just luck, really.
This post is about that hidden force ‚Äî how it works, how it deceives us, and how it affects players, coaches, analysts, and fans alike.
With a simple simulation, some stats, and a bit of honest thinking about how we judge performances, we‚Äôre going to break down how luck often looks like talent or failure. And how regression to the mean offers a much-needed antidote.
Let‚Äôs begin there.

First-Half Narratives: ‚ÄúExceptional!‚Äù ‚ÄúAverage‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúBench him!‚Äù
I‚Äôve deliberately hidden these players‚Äô second-half ratings. Before revealing them, I‚Äôd like you to think deeply about the following questions:

How do you think these players performed in the second half?
Who would you trust going forward?
Who would you praise or criticize based on just this half-season snapshot?

Pause here. Consider carefully before continuing. Make explicit or mental judgments based on the data you‚Äôve seen so far.
I know‚Äîit‚Äôs challenging to guess solely from these dots. To help you internalize, let me offer three relatable player narratives corresponding to each of the three groups.
Right now, you might be thinking something along these lines:

üü¢ For the top performers:
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs exceptional! Clearly, a talent we can build around. He‚Äôs the future. We should renew his contract, or if we had to sell him, we should expect extreme amounts!‚Äù


üîµ For the average performers:
‚ÄúSolid player, but maybe lacking ambition. We need more exciting talent‚Äîsomeone who clearly makes a difference.‚Äù


üî¥ For the worst performers:
‚ÄúHe looks lethargic, uninterested. He simply doesn‚Äôt have the mental toughness to succeed at this level. Bench him.‚Äù

These reactions are natural to the human mind, yet they might also be premature.
Just about a second when you scroll down, you might encounter something counter-intuitive for you. Below, you‚Äôll see the same players‚Äô second half performances, too.

For better tracking, I prepared the observations in a way that lets you follow the players left to right on the x-axis. For example, you can now trace exactly how each top performer ended up performing in the second half, based on our modest simulation.
Also, the legend provides the average change in performance for each group ‚Äî which is super useful context.


Turns Out, the Story Changes‚Ä¶
When we reveal the hidden half, something remarkable happens:

üü¢ Top performers generally decline slightly, not catastrophically, but still, you can observe an evident decline. Also, enough to disappoint inflated expectations.
üîµ Average players mostly remain stable in average rating. But they ended up going both ways.
üî¥ Worst performers notably improve, challenging the assumptions of incompetence or low motivation.

But most importantly, they distributed almost homogenously. We don‚Äôt see three player categories conserved the distinction between them. This image is a visual representation of regression to the mean in action.

Length: shows how much the performance regressed toward the mean.

title: The Illusion of Form: Regression to the Mean in Football
section: Regression Check: A Slope That Reveals the Pull
text:
Regression Check: A Slope That Reveals the Pull
While our simulation illustrates how extremes tend to drift toward the average, we can also show it quantitatively via a simple linear regression. If we take each player‚Äôs first-half performance as a predictor and plot their second-half performance against it, we can fit a regression line to see how well one half predicts the other.
Specifically, if we take each player‚Äôs first-half rating as an independent variable (predictor) and second-half rating as the dependent variable (outcome), we typically see a regression slope less than 1. In a perfectly consistent world, the dots would fall on a 45-degree diagonal line ‚Äî where every extreme performance repeats itself. That diagonal has a slope of 1.
In a simple linear regression of; \[\text{Second-Half Performance} = \text{ a } x \text{ b } x \text{ First-Half Performance } \] the coefficient b (the ‚Äúslope‚Äù) tells us how strongly the second-half scores scale with the first-half scores. A slope of 1 would mean that a player 1 point above average in the first half is predicted to be exactly 1 point above average in the second half. In other words, there would be no ‚Äúpull‚Äù back toward the average.
But, because of the luck factors, the line we actually get isn‚Äôt that steep. It‚Äôs flatter. In our simulation, the regression line has a slope less than 1 because we added luck factor to true skill. That number might seem small, but it‚Äôs doing something big:
That number might seem small, but it‚Äôs doing something big:

It pulls high performers down: If someone was far above average in the first half, the regression line predicts they‚Äôll be closer to average in the second half.
It pulls low performers up: If someone struggled early, it suggests they‚Äôll bounce back ‚Äî also drifting toward the middle.

Check this plot out:

fig, ax = plot_regression_with_highlighted_groups(df, best_fh, worst_fh, avg_fh)
plt.show()








Why does that happen? Because football performance ‚Äî like many things in life ‚Äî is a mix of skill and randomness. And since randomness is unpredictable, the correlation between the two halves isn‚Äôt perfect. The slope reflects that imperfection. The less perfect the link, the more the extremes ‚Äúshrink‚Äù toward the average. That‚Äôs regression to the mean in action ‚Äî visualized.
